thread.title: Bull Flees Queens Slaughterhouse, but Reprieve is Brief - The New York Times
thread.title_full: Bull Flees Queens Slaughterhouse, but Reprieve is Brief - The New York Times

author: Andy Newman
title: Bull Flees Queens Slaughterhouse, but Reprieve is Brief - The New York Times
text: Continue reading the main story Photo A bull led its owners and the police on a chase after escaping from a slaughterhouse in Queens on Tuesday. Credit Theodore Parisienne A bull escaped from a Queens slaughterhouse on Tuesday and was free on the streets for two hours, but died after being captured, the police said. The black bull ran away from the Aziz Slaughter House on Beaver Road in Jamaica shortly after 10 a.m., the police said. By 10:20 a.m. the police were receiving 911 calls about a “vicious animal” right across from the Jamaica train hub on Archer Avenue, Detective Ahmed Nasser, a police spokesman, said. The police shot the bull with several tranquilizer darts, but it kept moving. Video from a news helicopter showed the animal trotting down streets and onto lawns, with a police car in slow pursuit. Police are trying to capture a runaway cow on the loose in Jamaica, Queens, NY. https://t.co/mID9x6wZyx pic.twitter.com/LxY7egM90O — ABC News (@ABC) Feb. 21, 2017 The bull was cornered two miles from the train station in a yard on Marsden Street. But it escaped again, trudging along for an additional half mile before sitting in a yard on 158th Street and 116th Avenue around 12:20 p.m. An animal sanctuary in New Jersey agreed to take the bull, and the authorities drove it to a city shelter in East New York, Brooklyn, to await pickup. But the bull was pronounced dead there at 1:50 p.m. the police said. Escaped livestock are relatively common in New York City, which has dozens of slaughterhouses.
